header.name: chaos/preprocessor/algorithm/for_each_product.h
header.author: Paul Mensonides
header.overview: The header defines an algorithm that repeats a user-specified target for each Cartesian product of elements in a of .

macro.abstract: The macro repeats the target specified by its first argument for each Cartesian product of elements in its second argument.

macro.para: The macro itself expands to a in terms of (s). This , when invoked by , expands to the result of the repeated invocation of the target for each Cartesian product in seq.

The target is invoked with the current (s), a of elements representing a Cartesian product (product), and, if it exists, the auxiliary data (data or __VA_ARGS__). This target may expand to a in terms of (s). This allows the target to recurse on itself if necessary.

In C99, it is possible to omit the auxiliary data argument altogether. This is different than passing "nothing" as the auxiliary data.
#define A () (a, b, c) #define B () (x, y, z)
( (MACRO, (A)(B),) // #1 (MACRO, (A)(B)) // #2 )
The first line passes "nothing" as the auxiliary data, which causes MACRO to be invoked as (e.g.)... MACRO(s, (a)(x),) The second line omits the auxiliary data, which causes MACRO to be invoked as (e.g.)... MACRO(s, (a)(x)) The fundamental difference is that, in the first line, the auxiliary data is empty (which might have a valid meaning as data), but, in the second line, there is no auxiliary data. Hence, the algorithm is overloaded on a .
Invocations of the target are trampolined such that each invocation is invoked with (s), where s is the original at the beginning of the algorithm (i.e. ()). This maximizes the utility of the .

Ignoring the complexity of macro (which is invoked once for each Cartesian product), the running time of can be described in terms of the number of required to complete the algorithm. The asymptotic upper and lower bounds are Θα, where n is the number of elements in seq and nk is the number of elements in the k-th element of seq. (This formula can also be expressed functionally as Θ(f(n)+1), where f is F, which might be easier to conceptualize.)

Ignoring macro once again, the efficiency of the algorithm's use of the can be described in terms of the total depth of required to complete the algorithm. The asymptotic upper and lower bounds are Θβ, where n is the number of elements in seq and nk is the number of elements in the k-th element of seq.
